thread.title: Ioannidis has big impact on Temple defense
thread.title_full: Ioannidis has big impact on Temple defense

title: Ioannidis has big impact on Temple defense
text:
Marc Narducci, Inquirer Staff Writer Posted: Thursday, October 15, 2015, 3:01 AM 
When defensive tackle Matt Ioannidis enrolled in Temple, he came with the simplest of mind-sets. Coming out of Hunterdon Central High in New Jersey, he never envisioned the current state of the program, where the Owls are 5-0 heading into Saturday's 7:30 p.m. American Athletic Conference game at Lincoln Financial Field against Central Florida (0-6). 
"I didn't have a plan when I came here," he said. "I figured I was coming to Temple to play ball." 
And play ball is what he has done. 
Ioannidis never redshirted, playing the final six games of his freshman season as a reserve. More coverage SHOP: Collegiate Sportswear & Merchandise 
The 6-foot-4, 292-pound Ioannidis started seven games as a sophomore, including the final three. He has been a fixture ever since. Saturday Ioannidis is expected to make his 21st consecutive start. His 20th last week was among his best. 
Among the strongest players on the team, Ioannidis recorded six tackles and 11/2 sacks, both season highs in last week's 49-10 win over Tulane. 
He wasn't overly impressed with his performance and due to his team-first nature, never really worries about personal statistics. 
"I care about winning, about being 1-0 every week and I care about the defense playing well," he said. 
There has been a lot to care about so far this season. 
Temple is allowing 14.4 points per game, which is first in the AAC and 13th nationally. 
Ioannidis is one of those selfless players who often takes on multiple blockers, freeing up gaps for his teammates. 
"His job is to dominate inside," Temple coach Matt Rhule said of Ioannidis. "Whether he gets tackles or not, doesn't matter." 
Still, he has contributed his share of big plays this year. In the opening 27-10 win over Penn State, he had four tackles, two tackles for loss and a sack. For the season he has 13 tackles, 31/2 tackles for loss, 21/2 sacks and one fumble recovery. 
More than the statistics, the Owls have benefited from his no-nonsense approach, his work ethic and leadership. 
"He is a leader and a tough guy," Rhule said. "He holds people accountable, as well as himself." 
Ioannidis is also among the smartest players, rarely out of position. In addition, he is on schedule to graduate in December, earning a degree in communications in 31/2 years. 
For somebody who didn't have a plan, things have gone well for Ioannidis, who is among many Temple players considered NFL prospects. 
Most of all, Ioannidis is enjoying the winning this season. The Owls were 12-23 his first three seasons, although Temple was 6-6 last year. 
"I didn't think any of this would happen," he said. "I didn't expect such a great turnaround."
